item.title: The movie: "Babel"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: I felt like yelling at the screen, "If you do that you'll ruin your life! Ok, you can still recover as long as you don't even think about... never mind."

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded:
In my ordinary writing, I figure why use 5 words when I could use 500? So this blog is an exercise in brevity. If it ever takes longer than 5-seconds to read a review, you'll know I've been abducted. You can thank Sarah Hohman for the blog—she called my 5-second reviews on Facebook, "very entertaining". The idea is not original. But I hope my reviews are. Or at least entertaining. Jerit Wendlandt asked a Once Asked Question (an OAQ):
So your reading like a book a day and watching the extended versions of already long movies? How is this possible?
Well... I've got 30-something years of 5-second reviews just waiting to show the world. Plus it forms an important part of my Structured Procrastination strategy. What I do is to reduce thousands (or even millions) of man-hours of creative labor into a 5-second (or less!) blurb that probably misses the whole point of the work. It's like summarizing:
The throng of people hurried by, in two opposite streams, with no symptom of cessation or exhaustion; intent upon their own affairs; and undisturbed in their business speculations, by the roar of carts and waggons laden with clashing wares, the slipping of horses' feet upon the wet and greasy pavement, the rattling of the rain on windows and umbrella-tops, the jostling of the more impatient passengers, and all the noise and tumult of a crowded street in the high tide of its occupation: while the two poor strangers, stunned and bewildered by the hurry they beheld but had no part in, looked mournfully on; feeling, amidst the crowd, a solitude which has no parallel but in the thirst of the shipwrecked mariner, who, tost to and fro upon the billows of a mighty ocean, his red eyes blinded by looking on the water which hems him in on every side, has not one drop to cool his burning tongue.—The Old Curiosity Shop, Chapter 44
With:
Water, water, everywhere, And not a drop to drink.
Which misquotes The Rime of the Ancient Mariner. Perhaps it's a waste of time, but you can risk 5 seconds, can't you?

item.title: The book: "A Game of Thrones"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Kinda like an R-rated Dune.   More like X.

item.title: My 1999 Chevy S-10 pickup
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Oh that? It's no big deal. You'll get used to it after a while. I wouldn't worry about that other thing either.

item.title: The movie: "War Horse"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Thanks to green screens and CGI, no animals were harmed in the making of this film.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] I posted my 5-second review of War Horse on Facebook, I commented: Also, according to the credits, it was formally a book and a play! How do [...]

item.title: Follow-up on "War Horse":
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: When I posted my 5-second review of War Horse on Facebook, I commented: "Also, according to the credits, it was formally a book and a play! How do you do that story as a play? (My guess is that all the violent action scenes are off stage and they used stuffed horse.)" My dad answered: "According to Wikipedia, a manually operated tank, line-drawings on a screen, and puppets. See the TED talk at: [youtube http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h7u6N-cSWtY&w=560&h=315] My favourite quote from that TED Talk: ‎"An actor struggles to die on stage and a puppet struggles to live." The play is coming to Los Angeles this summer—I gotta see if I can get tickets.

item.title: Coffee: Starbuck's Caffe Verona®
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: A full-bodied, multi-region blend of... Who am I kidding? It's free at work and has caffeine.

item.title: The movie: "The Fellowship of the Ring"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: How could they make this without including Tom Bombadil, Farmer Maggot, or Glorfindel?!? Also, 178 minutes is way too long!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: And anyone who watches the "Theatrical" version instead of the "Extended" version is clearly a HERETIC! (Yes, all those ideas do fit in my head. Why do you ask?)

item.title: TV series: The first season of "Lost"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: "Let's watch the next episode so we can return the DVD to Netflix. I hope they don't screw up the ending of this show with some lame new-age/postmodern mumbo-jumbo..."

item.title: Website: Google Plus
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: I'm going to guess that a huge percentage of posts here right now are along the lines of: "Now what?"

item.title: The book: "A Clash of Kings"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Boiled leather, direwolves, and made-up religions.

item.title: The Resturant: Roscoe's House of Chicken 'n Waffles
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: What you need to know is they use coffee urns to dispense syrup and no amount of scrubbing can get the sticky off of the table tops. But I guarantee the fried chicken put that out of your mind until later in the day.

item.title: Website: Facebook
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Video games for girls.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: That was what I first thought (and said out loud) when Joy signed up for Facebook and suddenly I couldn't use the computer. It was also before Facebook got actual games.

item.title: Age: The third grade
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Old enough to be reasonably helpful—not so old as to know better.

item.title: The book: "The Book of Three"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Piglings and gigglings.

item.title: The Movie: "The Count of Monte Cristo" (2002)
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: I imagine Victor Hugo rolled over in his grave when this was released: not one actor even fakes a French accent. But I guess it's better to have everyone speak in vaguely English accents than in truly outrageous French ones. Also, see the guy who played Jesus play an atheist.

item.title: The movie: "The Lady Vanishes"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Remember that old cartoon with Bugs Bunny and Yosemite Sam fighting for the affections of an little, old lady? She's this film's MacGuffin.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: If you'd like to see what the fuss is all about archive.org has you covered: http://archive.org/details/lady_vanishes

item.title: Age: 8 years
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Honestly, was there ever an age when the world opened up as much as it does for an eight-year-old? It's exciting and scary, so having a parent's hand to hold, a good book to read, and plenty of friends can make a all the difference.

item.title: Website: Wikipedia
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Many[which?] internet users[dead link] consider Wikipedia to be the most interesting[editorializing] source of information every devised.[citation needed]

item.title: The Movie: "The Open Plains"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Kevin Costner, Robert Duvall, and Annette Bening play Kevin Costner, Robert Duvall, and Annette Bening as actors in a western.

item.title: A person: Joy
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded:
Five seconds is far too short to tell the story of my wife. In honor of our tenth anniversary: 1. She's great fun to get married to. We had the most enjoyable wedding day, which she planned to perfection. 2. Although she doesn't like hearing puns on her name, she gives me and many others a deep and abiding joy that isn't just shallow happiness. 3. Nobody, and I mean nobody, cares about people as much as my wife. Not just family and friends, but everybody. 4. Can you translate seamlessly from Spanish to English? English to Spanish? A language you've never learned (Italian) to English? She can. 5. When it comes to parenting, we are almost always on the same wavelength. It's a rare thing to never need to question the judgement of your spouse they need to teach or discipline your child. 6. Nobody knows me as well: she got me a Kindle Touch, which even I didn't know I wanted. 7. "Confidence" was a word coined for people like Joy. What's more, she's very good at instilling confidence in others when they/I need it. 8. Adventures with Joy (like hiking back to our car in the dark with steep cliffs on both sides of the trail) are more fun and rewarding than solo adventures. We make a great team. 9. I really can't imagine being married to anyone else. This life is the one I'd chose and share with her if I didn't already have it. 10.
By yourself you're unprotected. With a friend you can face the worst. Can you round up a third? A three-stranded rope isn't easily snapped.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] with a white bow tie and Joy is standing next to me looking especially radiant. It’s been 10 years and she looks even better today. Share this:TwitterFacebookLike this:LikeBe the first to like this. [...]

item.title: The book: "Pride and Prejudice"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded:
A guest review from Mark Twain:
Every time I read 'Pride and Prejudice' I want to dig her up and beat her over the skull with her own shin-bone.
(Hat tip: John Freiberg)

item.title: The Movie: "Toy Story"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: I think I figured out where they got the name: half of the movie charms the audience by the computer technology and the toys-as-people-when-not-looking conceit (the "Toy" part). But the other half is an engaging story, which is just as well since the novelties wears off over time.

item.title: Device: iPod Shuffle (Second Generation)
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Fun fact: I never use the shuffle mode.

item.title: Place: Hawaii
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Paradise or prison? Depends on how long you've been here.

item.title: The Movie: "Jurassic Park"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Dinosaurs are awesome! Playing God? Not so much.

item.title: The Book: "Prince Caspian"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Certainly the That Hideous Strength of The Chronicles of Narnia.

item.title: The Movie: "The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Certainly the Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull of The Chronicles of Narnia.

item.title: Telescope: Astroscan 2001
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: I bought it for a once-in-a-lifetime event (Halley's Comet) and 26 years later saw a twice-in-a-lifetime event (the transit of Venus). I've used the 'scope to observe a partial and a total solar eclipse. It still looks futuristic and functions perfectly despite being a one-time home for a spider.

item.title: The Book: "The Da Vinci Code"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Reads like "The Hardy Boys: The Abe Lincoln Caper" in which a series of clues reveals our 16<sup>th</sup> President to be a Confederate spy.

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: Book: “Truth and Fiction in The Da Vinci Code” « 5 second review
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] of maybe a dozen pages turns out to be far more interesting than anything in Dan Brown’s entire novel. It’s also full of genuinely controversial material that’s taken seriously by actual [...]

item.title: The Book: "Fahrenheit 451"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: The movie was better. Books are boring.

item.title: Device: iPod Touch
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Mobile internet browser, Kindle for low-light situations, and temporary child entertainment.

item.title: Car: Mazda 3
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: The model I drove on Kaua'i had a semi-manual transmission or as Joy called it, my new favorite toy.

item.title: The Movie: "Everything Must Go"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: A story about a man who has destroyed his life via alcoholism ought to be way more depressing and less funny than this.

item.title: The Book: "No Country for Old Men"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: I guess if you write like Cormac McCarthy, you dont need punctuation so much.

item.title: TV: "The Office" (US)
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Especially when Michael Scott was working at Scranton, every episode is the most excruciating experience imaginable. Why is this so funny?

item.title: Book: "The Blind Side"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Since reading it, I stopped watching the ball and started watching the huge giants push each other around at the line of scrimage. Also, I now notice when a quarterback is blessed with more than three or so seconds to scan downfield.

item.title: The Movie: "Office Space"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: So many quotable lines; so few lines I would be comfortable quoting. Also, why do white people like gangsta rap so much? (Present company excluded, of course.)

item.title: Place: Flying W Ranch
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Underneath the tourist-trap schlock was a temple to the Spirit of the West. The Flying W always reinvented itself, but never lost it's tradition of commitment to hard work, family values, tasty food, and Western (not Country) music. Like the phoenix, it will surely rise again.

item.title: The Movie: "Raiders of the Lost Ark"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Call me weird, but even with all the great action sequences, brilliant comedy, gorgeous location shots, trilling music, and startling special effects, my favorite part of the movie is the long exposition scene where we find out why the Nazis are interested in the Ark of the Covenant.

item.title: The Movie: "Independence Day"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Will Smith punches an alien! Bill Pullman flies an F-18 and is president! Jeff Goldblum nerds out (again) and saves the world with an Apple! (That's not what I learned in Sunday school...) Other A-list actors do stuff! Yawn.

item.title: Coffee: Kauai Coffee Estate Reserve Peaberry - Dark Roast
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: One problem with flying to Hawaii, visiting the Kauai plantation, testing a dozen varieties of coffees, and picking out the most expensive is that you can never tell if you are suffering confirmation bias. Thankfully, Jeni told me this coffee tasted good (black even) before I told her my tale.

item.title: Place: ComedySportz Los Angeles
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County is awash with comedy clubs, so what makes this one different? Well, it isn't stand-up, but "competitive improv". It's also "clean". (There's a foul if anyone is foul.) And it's cheap (call ahead for a discount), free parking is available, and it makes me laugh.

item.title: Movie: "Mission: Impossible II"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: I think this is the first movie I ever fell asleep watching in the theater. Yes I was critically sleep-deprived, but I think there was nothing to the film but action sequences. It's hard to care about a character in mortal danger when you don't really know who they are or why they do what they do.

item.title: Movie: "Mission: Impossible - Ghost Protocol"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Brad Bird ("The Incredibles") directed and it makes all the difference. I skipped the third installment (I think) so there's some continuity and character development material that didn't resonate, but the classic caper setups and resolutions worked. Well done.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: This was a let-down simply because the 3rd was so much better than any of the others. This one fit well with the two before the 3rd though. I'd suggest you watch the third but it might ruin the rest of the series for you to see how good it *could* have been.

item.title: Movie: "Brave"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: King Fergus was not voiced by John Cleese, but by the guy from "Mrs. Brown" who looks (and apparently, sounds) just like him. Among Pixar movies, this rates just above "WALL-E".

item.title: Book: "Crime and Punishment"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Raskolnikov really isn't any different from me except for circumstance. That makes this novel so harrowing and so brilliant. Splaying open the inner-working of our souls pains us, but does great good as well. Avoid it at your own peril.

item.title: Movie: The Peacemaker
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: A big, dumb, Hollywood action flick that makes one good decision: giving the bad guy a sympathetic back story. But then it messes the whole thing up by focusing on George Clooney and Nicole Kidman's surprisingly dull relationship.

item.title: Book: "Truth and Fiction in The Da Vinci Code"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Bart D. Ehrman's dissection of maybe a dozen pages turns out to be far more interesting than anything in Dan Brown's entire novel. It's also full of genuinely controversial material that's taken seriously by actual historians. Worth reading even if you disagree with his conclusions.

item.title: Movie: "The Blind Side"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: When I read the book, I pictured a woman exactly like Sandra Bullock. I normally dislike her as an actress, but she nailed this role. The best part of the film is seeing the actual pictures of Michael Oher and his adopted family. And yes, I cried when I read the book too.

item.title: Movie: "Batman Begins"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Until I saw this, I had no idea of the deep connections between the Jedi and the Batman.

item.title: Car: Volkswagen New Beetle
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: (And not the new New Beetle, which is just the Beetle.) Utterly fails my test in which I push the driver seat all the way back and see if I can sit comfortably behind it. The slanting rear window forces me to twist my head and duck on every bump. Also, works better for my boss's teenage daughter than for him.

item.title: Movie: "Watchmen"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: For me, the climax of the film was the opening title sequence, which was a montage of alternate history scenes. So it's odd that the message of the ending seems to be that this world is important because it happened one way and not another.

item.title: The book: "A Storm of Swords"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Word to the wise: don't get attached to any of the characters. Death is swift, brutal, and unannounced in this series. (But it's not always permanent.)

item.title: Book: "The Cost of Discipleship"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Jesus proposed a beautifully simple way to make the world a better place: put the needs of others above your own. Bonhoeffer, writing in the early years of Hitler's Germany, showed us how apply that idea.

item.title: Service: Charter TV
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: So the DVR is junk and cable TV is expensive, but we wanted to watch the Olympics and that's about it. Considering that establishing and cancelling was free and smooth, Charter did what we needed.

item.title: The Movie: The Lorax
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: There are many challenges to filming a 45 page picture book, but why didn't the press report on the devastation outside of town or the corruption of the (new) villain? Dr. Seuss might have been writing about current social issues, but he set his stories well outside of any specific place or time.

item.title: People: Canadians
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Does everyone already know that Canadians apologize for being Canadian? Oh. I'm sorry for wasting your time.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Question: How many Canadians does it take to unscrew a light bulb? Answer: Who cares, eh?

item.title: The Movie: "Clue"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Proof positive that a quality film can be built around a board game theme. The actual game would be greatly improved with the addition of Tim Curry whisking the players from one room to another in the final act.

item.title: Movie: "The Five-Year Engagement"
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Would someone please tell Jason Segel that his rear end isn't really all that funny?

item.title: Book: Unbroken
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: This is one of those "truth is stranger than fiction" books. It is, thankfully, carefully supported with endnotes and, more important, exceptionally well written and engrossing. Please find a copy and read!

item.title: Movie: Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: The visual effects don't hold up, but it doesn't matter because it's a musical and Gene Wilder became Willy Wonka.

item.title: People: Conservatives
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: A conservative is a person who optimistically believes "it's always been done this way" because someone in the past hit upon the best possible solution. (Of course, that person must have been a liberal.)

item.title: People: Liberals
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: A liberal knows exactly what's right for you and is eager to conduct a grand social experiment to prove themselves wrong.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Definition of political correctness: A pitiful attempt by mankind to please all, disguise the truth, and fail at both.
And of course YOU know what's right for me and can't be proven wrong?
You might want to look at the companion review of conservatives. Both are sort of silly if taken to extremes, know what I mean?

item.title: The Book: How to Win Friends and Influence People
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Dale Carnegie recounts 100s of anecdotes about how treating people the way you would like to be treated can be profitable. The subtitle could have been The Golden Rule for Selfish People.

item.title: Monsters Inc.
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Official film of this blog due to the final 5 seconds, which comprise the most wonderfully moving moment in cinematic history.

item.title: Daddy's Diaper & Delivery Duty
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: Guaranteed to get you clean, dry, and transferred to mommy any time of the day or night. (We cannot ensure our agent will not be grouchy, however.)

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: Invasion of the vampire babies! | Taking a one and one
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: […] In addition to a newborn’s aptitude for sleep for the first week or two (they don’t have much else they can do), parents are lulled into complacency by the wonderful nurses who swoop in to take care of their infant’s every need. When you get home, that job belongs to someone else. […]

item.title: Website: Lumosity
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: An excuse for executives to play games at work.

item.title: Advertisement: TurboTax 2014
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: The simple genius of the spot is that it puts a human face on the questions the IRS asks of us each year.

item.title: Closure
item.dc:creator: jlericson

item.title: Movie: Lone Survivor
item.dc:creator: jlericson
item.content:encoded: A vivid demonstration of why Thelma & Louise ended when they went over the cliff.
